image.altText: A barge at a port

items.synopsis: The British government says it's trying to "stop the boats", but one of its solutions — a giant, grey barge designed to house 500 asylum seekers — is proving controversial.

title.children: There's a floating 'recipe for disaster' off England's coast — it has links to Australia

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

items.synopsis: A COVID-19 variant nicknamed "Eris" — after the Greek goddess of chaos, strife and discord — has been in the news after spreading overseas. But the variant has actually been in Australia for four months.

title.children: The newly famous 'goddess of chaos' variant is making headlines, but it's been lurking quietly for months

image.altText: Actors.

items.synopsis: In India, the Modi government is accused of waging a war on Bollywood and using it for party propaganda.

title.children: 'You have to suck up or shut up': The clampdown on Bollywood's unforgivable sin

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander agencies, Voice to Parliament advocates and the prime minister have described a conspiracy theory on the length of Uluru Statement from the Heart as a misinformation campaign to avoid debating the facts.

title.children: Voice to Parliament conspiracy theory an attempt to create 'misinformation and division'

image.altText: Close-up of Michael Buckland wearing a lab coat

items.synopsis: If pathologists start looking for CTE in the brains of domestic violence victims, will they find it? And what will it mean if they do?

title.children: The first female athlete with CTE was diagnosed in Australia — but there are roadblocks to testing domestic violence victims

image.altText: Graphic of Australian Bank logos on houses including Commonwealth, ANZ, Westpac, and National.

items.synopsis: The big banks were offering cashback deals and competitive rates to grab their share of the refinancing boom, but the trend has reversed as margins start to come under pressure, leaving some borrowers trapped between a mortgage cliff and a mortgage prison.

title.children: Why the honeymoon is over — banks pull back on fight for new borrowers

image.altText: An ambulance is parked at an emergency department entrance car port, trees, shrubs.

items.synopsis: An overseas-trained and unregistered doctor lied to hospital staff about the progress of his registration application, two investigations have found.

title.children: Unregistered doctor 'lied' to gain access to regional hospital's ED, investigations reveal

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: About 30 per cent of Australians live in rental accommodation with growing numbers in seats that helped secure government for Labor. But the Greens want to win those votes and next week's National Cabinet will offer clues as to how determined Labor is to stop them, writes David Speers.

title.children: Next week holds an important moment for housing policy — and renters are gaining influence

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses and a red jacket

items.synopsis: Legislation to establish the Parliamentary Workplace Support Service is the first major tranche of legislation to deal with the recommendations made by former Sex Discrimination Commissioner.

title.children: Legislation to establish parliament human resources agency tabled two years after sexual harassment review

image.altText: A photo taken from the road of a huge orange blaze against the black smoke in the sky.

items.synopsis: Wildfires in Hawaii burn multiple structures and force evacuations from popular tourist areas, as rescuers pull a dozen people escaping smoke and flames from the ocean.

title.children: Six killed in Hawaii as wildfires force people to flee into ocean

image.altText: Filipino marines standing on the deck of a rusty ship.

items.synopsis: For decades the Philippines have stationed a small contingent of marines on a rusting World War II warship that was deliberately run aground on a submerged reef in the South China Sea.

title.children: Why a dilapidated wreck has become a flashpoint for conflict between China and the Philippines

image.altText: organe faced man with blonde hair

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Twitter fined $350k for failing to hand over Trump data: The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Sixto Rodriguez, who lived in obscurity as his music career flamed out early in the US only to find success in Australia and South Africa, has died at 81. His death was announced on the Sugarman.org website and confirmed by his granddaughter, Amanda Kennedy. He died following a short illness, according to his wife Konny Rodriguez, 72. Rodriguez's legacy took off after the singer and songwriter became the subject of the Oscar-winning documentary, Searching for Sugar Man. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sixto Rodriguez, subject of searching for Sugar Man documentary dead at 81

featuredLink.title: Rodriguez, subject of Searching for Sugar Man documentary, dies at 81

children.content: Sixto Rodriguez, who lived in obscurity as his music career flamed out early in the US only to find success in Australia and South Africa, has died at 81.
His death was announced on the Sugarman.org website and confirmed by his granddaughter, Amanda Kennedy.
He died following a short illness, according to his wife Konny Rodriguez, 72.
after the singer and songwriter became the subject of the Oscar-winning documentary, Searching for Sugar Man.
You can keep reading this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Six people are dead in Hawaii as a major wildfire burns parts of the US state's most popular tourist areas. Maui Mayor Richard Bissen confirmed the fatalities from the fire in the historic Lahaina town this morning. Wildfires in Hawaii fanned by strong winds burned multiple structures, forcing evacuations and closing schools in several communities and rescuers pulled a dozen people escaping smoke and flames from the ocean. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hawaiian wildfires kill 6 people

featuredLink.title: Six killed in Hawaii as wildfires force people to flee into ocean

children.content: Six people are dead in Hawaii as a major wildfire burns parts of the US state's most popular tourist areas.
Maui Mayor Richard Bissen confirmed the fatalities from the fire in the historic Lahaina town this morning.

Wildfires in Hawaii fanned by strong winds burned multiple structures, forcing evacuations and closing schools in several communities and rescuers pulled a dozen people escaping smoke and flames from the ocean.
You can keep reading this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lil Tay, a rapper who became an internet sensation at nine years old with her controversial videos, has died. Her family announced her passing on her Instagram, revealing that her brother had also died. The circumstances around her death are under investigation. "We have no words to express the unbearable loss and indescribable pain," it read. "The outcome was entirely unexpected, and has left us all in shock."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rapper and internet star Lil Tay dies, aged 14

children.content: Lil Tay, a rapper who became an internet sensation at nine years old with her controversial videos, has died.
Her family announced her passing on her Instagram, revealing that her brother had also died.
The circumstances around her death are under investigation.
"We have no words to express the unbearable loss and indescribable pain," it read.
"The outcome was entirely unexpected, and has left us all in shock."

image.altText: Wild Mushroom Death Cap

items.synopsis: The deaths of three Victorians after a Saturday lunch in the small town of Leongatha sent shock waves through the community, but also shone the spotlight on one of the most poisonous organisms on earth.

title.children: What happens when you eat a death cap mushroom?

image.altText: A clear zip lock bag with jellybeans and a vile of insulin inside.

items.synopsis: An Adelaide nightclub defends its handling of an incident in which a man with type 1 diabetes was questioned about his insulin — but said it would work to ensure such an occurrence "doesn't happen again".

title.children: Nightclub to 'fully educate' staff after young patron carrying insulin questioned

image.altText: A big slab of rock with a bone fossil of an ancient giant amphibian inside

items.synopsis: Almost 30 years after a chicken farmer found an almost perfectly preserved fossil in a slab of sandstone, scientists have identified the skeleton as a prehistoric amphibian.

title.children: 'An incredibly rare find': This ancient amphibian almost ended up forgotten inside a backyard renovation project

image.altText: Annie blows a whistle, standing alongside a rugby scrum in her jersey.

items.synopsis: Hardened rugby union referees are walking away from the game amid a dramatic surge in abuse, prompting Rugby Australia to dish out tougher sanctions to offenders.

title.children: 'You don't know the rules': Female referees report surge in abuse from spectators

image.altText: a camera and silhouette of a woman beside it

items.synopsis: The Queensland mother is facing the prospect of having nowhere to live after raising concerns about security cameras inside their rental property. She became so concerned she and her children left the property.

title.children: Sandy was told cameras in her rental home were inactive. Then she saw one light up

image.altText: A man in a black shirt and scar, arrives at a premiere, smiling to photographers

items.synopsis: The Canadian-born Robertson was a high school dropout who fell in love with the seemingly limitless sounds and byways of his adopted US.

title.children: Robbie Robertson, lead guitarist and songwriter of The Band, dies at 80

image.altText: A man in a hat and coat plays a guitar on stage.

items.synopsis: The singer died in Detroit after a short illness, according to his family.

title.children: Rodriguez, subject of Searching for Sugar Man documentary, dies at 81

image.altText: Rodriguez sits on the porch of a house

items.synopsis: Midnight Oil's former manager Zev Eizik booked the singer's first Australian tour in the 1970s. It didn't start off well.

title.children: Australia was early in embracing Rodriguez, a talent chewed up by the music industry

image.altText: Tasmania Police vehicles.

items.synopsis: The ex-girlfriend of a man accused of abusing her and three other women tells a court he would sometimes call police after he physically or sexually assaulted her, to imply he was the "victim, not the aggressor".

title.children: Man who allegedly abused four ex-girlfriends tried to be the 'victim' by phoning police first, court hears

image.altText: a man sitting behind a computer at a dining room table at home

items.synopsis: Larry took three jobs that were advertised and agreed upon as being work-from-home. Then the employers changed their minds.

title.children: Can employers advertise a job as work-from-home and then change their mind?

image.altText: man stands with back to camera looking at streetscape

items.synopsis: Asylum seekers say they want to live with dignity and contribute to the country that has taken them in, but declining government assistance makes that impossible.

title.children: After fleeing Iraq, Ali was left shocked when he was told what he had to provide to get government aid

image.altText: Four NT solar farms including ENI's Bachelor development are sitting idle

items.synopsis: The architect of the NT government's renewable energy road map says the jurisdiction is at risk of missing its 2030 target due to "unrealistic" regulation.

title.children: NT solar investment will 'fall flat on its face', government renewables expert warns

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair looking at the camera.

items.synopsis: Australians with mental health issues are the fastest-growing group needing specialist homelessness services, according to a federal government report. Here, a Queensland woman reveals how she has come to be among them.

title.children: Being abused as a child left Phoebe Staggard with ongoing trauma. It has also left her homeless

image.altText: A French World Cup player looks to her left during a match.

items.synopsis: France defender Ève Périsset is set to mark Caitlin Foord in Saturday's Women's World Cup quarterfinal, while helping  her teammates plot how they will handle Chelsea colleague Sam Kerr.

title.children: The French star with the tips on how to handle Foord, Kerr in World Cup clash against Matildas

image.altText: Two football players fight for control of the ball

items.synopsis: Almost a month after downing France in a friendly, the Matildas will look to build on what they learned in order to take the football powerhouse down again.

title.children: 'We learned a lot from that game': How the Matildas will look to exploit France's weaknesses

image.altText: Charlie Curnow flexes his muscle and yells in delight

items.synopsis: Charlie Curnow is on track for a second Coleman Medal in as many years. This is how Carlton is getting the best out of the multifaceted star key forward.

title.children: Behind Carlton spearhead Charlie Curnow's push for a second straight Coleman Medal

image.altText: Fans holding signs.

items.synopsis: Most people agree we're a bit over "Aussie, Aussie, Aussie, oi, oi, oi". So what are the alternatives and how do we get the whole crowd singing them at games, asks Dan Colasimone.

title.children: If not 'oi, oi, oi', what are the chants and songs to show support for the Matildas?

image.altText: Brittany looks into the camera, as other cameras are pointed at her while she walks along.

items.synopsis: Brittany Higgins breaks her silence for the first time since a report examining the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann was released.

title.children: Brittany Higgins speaks for first time since release of report into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

image.altText: Close up shot of an ibis, with a blurry background.

items.synopsis: The 60-year-old has been jailed after he pleaded guilty and was convicted on 10 counts of animal cruelty, shoplifting and drug possession.

title.children: Sydney man who decapitated and prepared to cook 'bin chicken' jailed for six months

image.altText: Jaq Grantford stands beside a large canvas mounted on a gallery wall.

items.synopsis: Jaq Grantford wins the Archibald People's Choice award for her portrait of former Play School presenter Noni Hazlehurst.

title.children: Former Play School star the face of Archibald People's Choice portraiture award

image.altText: Tasmanian Labor pamphlet mimicking a power bill

items.synopsis: Its layout and colour scheme are similar to an actual power bill — but if you look closer, it is a Labor attack on power prices under the Liberals, something the Tasmanian premier says is a "disgraceful scam" that has people "needlessly scared".

title.children: 'Disgraceful': Labor attack ad mocked-up as 'power bill' blasted by Tasmanian government

image.altText: A dark-skinned woman wearing a red scarf.

items.synopsis: As the Federal Court hears testimony from Pilbara elders, lawyers for Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Metals Group have continued to deny the iron ore miner is liable for compensation for traditional owners.

title.children: Elder says her community has been 'torn apart' by dispute with Andrew Forrest's FMG

image.altText: Three teen boys appear to be joking around, waiting in the shade amid peers, wear blue tee, some  scouts have scarf around neck.

items.synopsis: After a Herculean evacuation effort, Australia's 900 scouts and leaders have arrived in Seoul in what has become a World Scout Jamboree marred by extreme weather and infrastructure challenges.

title.children: Aussie scouts welcome Seoul hotel air-conditioning, crave 'unmelted' chocolate biscuits
